subject: RE: [junit] A Growing Problem
msgSnippet: On Wed, 2002-08-21 at 10:47, Stevens, Timothy J. (LNG-MBC) wrote: The number of tests that you have in your test class should be proportional to the number of
messageBody:
On Wed, 2002-08-21 at 10:47, Stevens, Timothy J. (LNG-MBC) wrote:

The number of tests that you have in your test class should be
proportional to the number of methods that you have in the class to be
tested. And, I wouldn't think you'd average more than three tests per method
to be tested.

I don't agree with any general attempt at correlating "domain" code and
test code. You write as many tests as you need to specify the behavior
you are attempting to achieve.

So, I'd say if you've got that many test methods floating about, you
may want to think about breaking up your classes somewhat. However, there's
nothing that says you can't create multiple test classes to test a single
class, then come up with some way to divvy up your tests (all null tests go
in one class, etc.).

Yes, TestCases aren't meant to correspond to classes begin
tested/driven. They are a fixture mechanism. The tests in a single
TestCase are there to use a common fixture. When you find that you need
to change the fixture (i.e. the setUp method), you should create a new
TestCase instead.

Dave
